We're living on an island with grey seals
surrounding the cottage.

8.text: It's quite interesting at night, when it goes dark, we can't go outside.

13.text: There's bull seals rampaging out there, there's fighting,

16.text: and we hear all the noises.

17.text: Then during the day, we open our doors,

19.text: and we can literally have grey seal pups at our feet.

30.text: So, this time of year, we're starting to see a lot more activity from the bull seals.

35.text: but they're also starting to fight as well.

37.text: They'll actually protect areas, and protect harems,

40.text: because they're trying to breed with these females.

43.text: And that's why all this fighting is occurring.

52.text: So grey seal pups are born at about 15 kilograms,

55.text: and they'll put about a kilogram a day of weight on,

58.text: and after three weeks, they're big animals,

60.text: about 45 kilograms in weight, when they're independent.

64.text: The female, well, she lactates, in those three weeks,

67.text: milk, which is very very rich in fat, about 60 percent fat,

71.text: and that's how they can put on this tremendous weight,

73.text: for survival in the North Sea.

76.text: So the National Trust bought the Farne Islands in 1925,

79.text: and since then they've been protecting and conserving this place.

82.text: It's such an important place, nationally and internationally,

85.text: and we've got to save this place for the future,

87.text: and that's what the National Trust are doing.
